modules.title: Output & Printing
modules.description: Learn to display text and numbers on screen ‚Äî The most fundamental tool in Python

content.explanation: The print() function is the most fundamental tool in Python. It displays information on the screen‚Äîtext, numbers, results of calculations, variables, and formatted output. In every program, debugging, interaction, or final result showing is done using print(). Think of print() as your direct communication channel from your program to the user.

analogy.description: Imagine you're in a train control room. You enter data into the system; the public display boards (screens) show the announcement. The public display = print(). Whatever you send ‚Äî Text, Numbers, Warnings, Status messages ‚Äî will appear for users to see.

keyNotes: Commas inside print add a space automatically
print() can evaluate expressions like print(10 + 5)

content.explanation: Python lets you print multiple lines easily using multiple print statements or using newline characters (\n) inside a single print. This helps when formatting reports, logs, or structured output.

content.explanation: A variable is a name that stores a value. Datatypes define the kind of data a variable contains‚Äînumbers, text, true/false, etc. Python automatically detects the datatype when you assign a value, making coding simpler and faster.

modules.title: Operators
modules.description: Learn how Python performs math, comparison, and logical operations

content.explanation: Arithmetic operators allow Python to perform basic mathematical operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, exponentiation, and modulo. They help you calculate values, build formulas, and process numerical data.

analogy.title: üßÆ Real-World Analogy: Calculator Buttons
analogy.description: Arithmetic operators are like the buttons on a calculator: + adds numbers, - subtracts, / divides, and % gives the remainder‚Äîjust like when you divide chocolates among friends and check how many are left.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# Basic Arithmetic
a = 10
b = 3

print(a + b)   # 13
print(a - b)   # 7
print(a * b)   # 30
print(a / b)   # 3.333...

# Floor Division
print(10 // 3)   # 3

# Modulo (Remainder)
print(10 % 3)    # 1

# Power / Exponent
print(2 ** 3)    # 8

content.explanation: Relational operators compare two values and return True or False. These are used in conditions, loops, and decision-making.

analogy.title: üìä Real-World Analogy: Comparing Marksheets
analogy.description: Comparing two marksheets: 'Is mark1 > mark2?', 'Is mark1 equal to mark2?' ‚Äî Just like real life comparisons, relational operators compare values.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:

print(5 < 3)     # False
print(10 == 10)  # True
print(10 != 5)   # True
print(7 >= 7)    # True
print(4 <= 2)    # False

content.explanation: Logical operators combine multiple conditions. They return True or False based on the relationship between statements.

analogy.title: üö™ Real-World Analogy: Security Door
analogy.description: A door opens only if: You have a key AND you press the button. This is 'and'. If either condition works, that's 'or'. 'not' reverses truth value.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:

print(x > 5 and x < 20)  # True
print(x > 5 or x < 5)    # True
print(not(x > 5))        # False

content.explanation: Python evaluates expressions based on priority of operators. This is called precedence. When two operators have the same priority, Python evaluates from left to right (associativity).

analogy.title: üìê Real-World Analogy: Math Class Rules
analogy.description: In maths: Multiplication before addition ‚Üí same rule here. BODMAS/PEMDAS rules apply in Python too.

modules.title: Strings
modules.description: Learn how to work with text, characters, slicing, and indexing in Python

content.explanation: A string is a sequence of characters enclosed inside quotes. Strings allow you to store names, addresses, sentences, or any textual data. They support indexing, slicing, and various built-in methods for manipulation. Python treats strings as immutable‚Äîmeaning once created, they cannot be altered directly.

analogy.title: üîê Real-World Analogy: Row of Lockers
analogy.description: Think of a string like a row of lockers, each locker holding a letter. Example: 'GOURI' ‚Äî Indexing means opening a specific locker. Slicing means selecting a range of lockers.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# Creating Strings
name = "Gouri"
city = 'Vizag'

# Multi-line Strings
text = """
Python is powerful.
Python is fun.
"""

# Concatenation
full = "Hello" + " " + "World"
print(full)

# Length of String
print(len("Python"))  # 6

content.explanation: Indexing accesses a single character using a number. Index starts from 0. Slicing retrieves parts of a string using [start:end].

analogy.title: üçû Real-World Analogy: Bread Slicing
analogy.description: Indexing = picking a specific letter from a word. Slicing = cutting a substring from the word like slicing a bread loaf.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# Indexing
name = "Python"
print(name[0])   # P
print(name[5])   # n

# Negative Indexing
print(name[-1])  # n
print(name[-3])  # h

# Slicing
print(name[0:3])  # Pyt
print(name[2:])   # thon
print(name[:4])   # Pyth

# Step Slicing
print(name[::2])  # Pto

content.explanation: Python provides built-in methods to transform strings: upper/lower, replace, count, find, split, etc.

print(text.find("o"))    # 4
print(text.count("l"))   # 3

modules.title: Conditionals
modules.description: Make decisions in your code with if, elif, and else statements

content.explanation: Conditionals let your program make decisions! The `if` statement checks a condition ‚Äî if it's True, the indented code runs. Use `else` for what happens when the condition is False. Use `elif` (else if) to check multiple conditions. This is the foundation of decision-making in programming.

analogy.title: üö¶ Real-World Analogy: Traffic Signal
analogy.description: Conditionals work like traffic rules. IF the light is green, you go. ELIF (else if) the light is yellow, you slow down. ELSE (red light), you stop. Your program checks conditions and takes different actions based on what's true.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax

content.explanation: Comparison operators are used inside conditions to compare values. They return True or False which determines which branch of code runs.

analogy.title: ‚öñÔ∏è Real-World Analogy: Judge's Decision
analogy.description: Like a judge comparing evidence to make a verdict, comparison operators compare values to determine the outcome.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# Comparison Operators
# ==  Equal to
# !=  Not equal to
# >   Greater than
# <   Less than
# >=  Greater than or equal
# <=  Less than or equal

x = 10
print(x == 10)  # True
print(x != 5)   # True
print(x > 5)    # True
print(x < 5)    # False
print(x >= 10)  # True
print(x <= 9)   # False

keyNotes: All comparisons return True or False

content.explanation: Logical operators (and, or, not) combine multiple conditions to create complex decision-making logic.

analogy.title: üîê Real-World Analogy: Bank Vault
analogy.description: A bank vault might need TWO keys (and), OR a manager's override (or). NOT reverses a condition‚Äîlike 'not locked' means open.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# Logical Operators
age = 25
has_license = True

# and - both must be True
if age >= 18 and has_license:
    print("You can drive!")

# or - at least one True
if age < 13 or age > 60:
    print("Special discount!")

# not - reverses the condition
is_raining = False
if not is_raining:
    print("Go outside!")

keyNotes: or requires AT LEAST ONE True

content.hint: Python checks conditions from top to bottom and stops at the first True.
commonDoubts: Does Python check all conditions?

content.explanation: Python checks conditions from top to bottom. The first condition (x > 5) is True, so it prints 'A' and skips ALL remaining elif/else blocks.

modules.title: Loops
modules.description: Automate repetitive tasks with for and while loops

content.explanation: Loops repeat code automatically! A `for` loop iterates over a sequence (like a range of numbers or characters in a string). A `while` loop keeps running as long as a condition is True. Loops are essential for automating repetitive tasks.

analogy.title: üîÑ Real-World Analogy: Assembly Line
analogy.description: Imagine an assembly line in a factory. A FOR loop is like saying 'paint exactly 100 cars' ‚Äî you know how many times to repeat. A WHILE loop is like saying 'keep painting cars until the paint runs out' ‚Äî you keep going until a condition changes.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# FOR loop with range
for i in range(5):        # 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
    print(i)

for i in range(1, 6):     # 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
    print(i)

for i in range(0, 10, 2): # 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 (step of 2)
    print(i)

# FOR loop with string
for char in "Python":
    print(char)  # P y t h o n (each on new line)

keyNotes: for loops iterate a known number of times
range(start, stop, step) for custom ranges
Strings can be iterated character by character

content.explanation: While loops continue executing as long as a condition remains True. They're useful when you don't know in advance how many iterations you need.

analogy.title: üéÆ Real-World Analogy: Video Game
analogy.description: A while loop is like playing a video game until you run out of lives. You keep playing (looping) while lives > 0.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# WHILE loop
count = 1
while count <= 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1  # Don't forget to update!

# Countdown example
n = 5
while n > 0:
    print(n)
    n -= 1
print("Blast off!")

keyNotes: while loops run as long as condition is True
Always update the loop variable to avoid infinite loops
Use when number of iterations is unknown

content.explanation: The `break` statement exits a loop immediately. The `continue` statement skips the current iteration and moves to the next one. These control statements give you fine-grained control over loop execution.

analogy.title: üö® Real-World Analogy: Emergency Exit
analogy.description: break is like an emergency exit ‚Äî you leave immediately. continue is like skipping a boring chapter ‚Äî you move to the next one without finishing the current.

modules.title: Functions
modules.description: Create reusable code blocks with functions

content.explanation: Functions are reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks. Define a function using `def function_name():`. Functions can accept inputs (parameters) and return outputs using `return`. This makes your code organized, reusable, and easier to debug.

analogy.title: üç≥ Real-World Analogy: Recipe Book
analogy.description: A function is like a recipe. You write it once (define it), and you can use it whenever you want (call it). The recipe might need ingredients (parameters) and produces a dish (return value). Just like you don't rewrite the recipe every time you cook, you don't rewrite code ‚Äî you just call the function!

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# Simple function (no parameters)
def greet():
    print("Hello, Welcome!")

greet()  # Call the function

# Function with parameters
def greet_user(name):
    print(f"Hello, {name}!")

greet_user("Rahul")    # Hello, Rahul!
greet_user("Priya")    # Hello, Priya!

keyNotes: Function names follow variable naming rules
Parameters are inputs to the function
Call a function by using its name with ()

content.explanation: Functions can return values using the `return` statement. The returned value can be stored in a variable or used directly. Functions without return statements return None by default.

analogy.title: üè≠ Real-World Analogy: Factory Output
analogy.description: A function is like a factory. You give it raw materials (parameters), it processes them, and gives you a finished product (return value).

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# Function with return value
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add(5, 3)     # result = 8
print(result)

# Multiple return values
def calculate(a, b):
    sum_val = a + b
    diff_val = a - b
    return sum_val, diff_val

s, d = calculate(10, 4)
print(f"Sum: {s}, Difference: {d}")

keyNotes: return sends a value back to the caller

content.explanation: Default parameters allow functions to have optional arguments with preset values. If the caller doesn't provide a value, the default is used.

analogy.title: ‚òï Real-World Analogy: Coffee Order
analogy.description: Like ordering coffee ‚Äî if you don't specify milk, they use the default (regular milk). But you can customize by specifying oat milk.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# Function with default parameter
def power(base, exp=2):
    return base ** exp

print(power(5))        # 25 (uses default exp=2)
print(power(5, 3))     # 125 (exp=3)

# Practical example
def greet(name, greeting="Hello"):
    print(f"{greeting}, {name}!")

greet("Gouri")              # Hello, Gouri!
greet("Gouri", "Welcome")   # Welcome, Gouri!

keyNotes: Put default parameters after required ones

content.explanation: Functions help organize code into logical, reusable pieces. Common patterns include validation functions, calculation functions, and utility functions.

analogy.title: üß∞ Real-World Analogy: Toolbox
analogy.description: Functions are like tools in a toolbox. Each tool has a specific purpose. You pick the right tool for the job and use it whenever needed.

syntax.title: üêç Python Syntax
syntax.code:
# Validation function
def is_even(number):
    return number % 2 == 0

print(is_even(4))   # True
print(is_even(7))   # False

# Calculation function
def calculate_area(length, width):
    return length * width

area = calculate_area(5, 3)
print("Area:", area)  # Area: 15

# Utility function
def format_name(first, last):
    return f"{first.title()} {last.upper()}"

print(format_name("john", "doe"))  # John DOE

keyNotes: Keep functions focused on one task

content.hint: What happens when x is exactly 0?
commonDoubts: What if no condition is True?
What does a function return by default?
Does every function need a return?
content.explanation: When x is 0, neither condition (x > 0 or x < 0) is True, so no return statement executes. In Python, if a function doesn't explicitly return something, it returns None by default.

questions.question: Which keyword is used to define a function?
questions.explanation: def is the keyword used to define functions in Python

questions.question: What does 'return' do in a function?
options: C) Sends a value back to caller
questions.explanation: return sends a value back to where the function was called

questions.question: What is returned by a function with no return statement?
questions.explanation: Functions without return statements return None by default

questions.question: Can a function call another function?
questions.explanation: Functions can call other functions, enabling code organization and reuse
